messages.title: A Better Future for the UK
messages.content: Investing in our schools. Tackling the climate emergency. Rejecting the politics of division and hate.

messages.title: Jo Swinson's Positive Plan for the UK
messages.content: Rebuild our economy and create more jobs. Invest in schools and our NHS. Tackle the climate emergency.

keyPolicies.policyTitle: Rebuild our economy and create more jobs
Invest in schools and our NHS

mentions.candidate: Jo Swinson: The UK's next Prime Minister

issues.brexitEurope: Stopping Brexit. Whether delivered by Jeremy Corbyn or Boris Johnson, Brexit will be disastrous for Britain. I believe there is no deal better than being a member of the EU. Any Brexit will be bad for jobs, restrict our rights and harm our ability to tackle the climate crisis.
issues.economy: Rebuild our economy and create more jobs
issues.health: Invest in schools and our NHS

leaflet.personalStatement: What got you into politics? When I was young, my Dad always taught me to believe that we can change things for the better. It started by signing Body Shop petitions as a teenager and I ran several campaigns when I was in university. I was MP for my area for a decade from 2005. I got back into politics in 2017 because I saw the direction the country was going in, and I knew we had to stand up for the open, liberal values I’ve fought for all my life. In the face of nationalism, hatred and Brexit, I couldn’t just stand by and do nothing.

quotes.text: Both the Conservatives and Labour look set to lose a majority of those who voted for them in the 2017 General Election.
Boris Johnson's adviser Dominic Cummings: Tory MPs 'don't care' about poorer people or NHS.
Three Labour Lords have quit the party over its handling of the anti-semitism.
Parliament suspension: Thousands protest across the UK.

examples: Both the Conservatives and Labour look set to lose a majority of those who voted for them in the 2017 General Election.

It started by signing Body Shop petitions as a teenager and I ran several campaigns when I was in university. I was MP for my area for a decade from 2005. I got back into politics in 2017 because I saw the direction the country was going in, and I knew we had to stand up for the open, liberal values I’ve fought for all my life. In the face of nationalism, hatred and Brexit, I couldn’t just stand by and do nothing.
